title: Death-Throws
text:
The Death-Throws are a team of supervillains appearing in <a href="American%20comic%20book">American comic book</a>s published by <a href="Marvel%20Comics">Marvel Comics</a>. They first appeared in "<a href="Captain%20America%20%28comic%20book%29">Captain America</a>" #317 (May 1986) and were created by <a href="Mark%20Gruenwald">Mark Gruenwald</a> and <a href="Paul%20Neary">Paul Neary</a>. Introduced as enemies of <a href="Hawkeye%20%28Clint%20Barton%29">Hawkeye</a>, the Death-Throws consists primarily of <a href="Juggling">jugglers</a> who each use various <a href="juggling%20prop">juggling prop</a>s as weapons.
Publication history.
Bombshell and Oddball first appeared in "<a href="Hawkeye%20%28Clint%20Barton%29">Hawkeye</a>" Vol.1 #3-4 (1983) and battled the title character. They later joined the juggling supervillain team known as the Death-Throws to face Hawkeye in the pages of "<a href="Captain%20America%20%28comic%20book%29">Captain America</a>" #317 (1986) and "<a href="Solo%20Avengers">Avengers Spotlight</a>" #23-25 (1989). Oddball battled Hawkeye once again in "Hawkeye: Earth's Mightiest Marksman" #1 (1998).
The Death-Throws later appeared in "<a href="Union%20Jack%20%28Joseph%20Chapman%29">Union Jack</a>" Vol.2 #1-2 (2006) and had cameo appearances in "Captain America" #411-414 (1993) and "" #27 (2009).The Death-Throws have also had notable entries in the "<a href="Official%20Handbook%20of%20the%20Marvel%20Universe">Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe</a>" Vol.2 (Deluxe Edition) #3 (1985) and "<a href="Dark%20Reign%20%28comics%29">Dark Reign</a> Files" #1 (2009).
The members of the Death-Throws have made various minor solo appearances. Bombshell has appeared in "Captain America" #388-392 (1991), "<a href="Spectacular%20Spider-Man">Spectacular Spider-Man</a> Annual" #12 (1992), "<a href="Web%20of%20Spider-Man">Web of Spider-Man</a> Annual" #8 (1992), "<a href="New%20Warriors">New Warriors</a> Annual" #2 (1992) and "Villains for Hire" #1-4 (2011). Oddball has featured in "Captain America" #395 (1991), "<a href="Guardians%20of%20the%20Galaxy%20%281969%20team%29">Guardians of the Galaxy</a>" #28 (1992) and "<a href="Wolverine%20%28comic%20book%29">Wolverine</a>" Vol.2 #167 (2001). Knickknack has had cameo appearances in "<a href="Thunderbolts%20%28comics%29">Thunderbolts</a>" #53 (2001), "Wolverine" Vol.3 #26 (2005) and "<a href="Dark%20Reign%20%28comics%29">Dark Reign</a>: <a href="Hood%20%28comics%29">The Hood</a>" #1 (2009).
<a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a>'s robotic army of Death T.H.R.O.W.S. have appeared in "<a href="Hawkeye%20%26amp%3B%20Mockingbird">Hawkeye & Mockingbird</a>" #2-5 (2010) and "<a href="Heroic%20Age%20%28comics%29">The Heroic Age</a>: Villains" #1 (2011).
Fictional team history.
The Ringleader and the Healey brothers (Oddball and Tenpin) came together to form the juggling-themed supervillain group, the Death-Throws. Knickknack was later recruited as the fourth member of the group. Oddball, given to his eccentric behaviour, quit the Death-Throws and branched out on his own. Oddball was hired, along with Bombshell, by <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a> to battle <a href="Hawkeye%20%28Clint%20Barton%29">Hawkeye</a> and <a href="Mockingbird%20%28Marvel%20Comics%29">Mockingbird</a>. The two supervillains subdued the heroes and delivered them to Crossfire. Later, when Hawkeye had managed to escape, Bombshell, Oddball and Crossfire were defeated and handed over to the authorities. Bombshell and Oddball were broken out of prison by Oddball's brother, Tenpin, and became members of the Death-Throws.
Oddball was contacted by Crossfire to break him out of prison. The Death-Throws took the job and were successful in their mission. But when Crossfire couldn't pay them for their services, the Death-Throws held him for ransom to lure Hawkeye into an ambush. The team were later defeated by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Captain%20America">Captain America</a>. Sometime later, Crossfire placed a bounty on archer's right arm as he attempted to gain revenge against Hawkeye. The Death-Throws (along with the <a href="Brothers%20Grimm%20%28comics%29">Brothers Grimm</a>, Bobcat, Bullet Biker, <a href="Mad%20Dog%20%28comics%29">Mad Dog</a>, and <a href="Razor%20Fist">Razor Fist</a>) looked to cash in on the reward. The group, along with the rest of the supervillains, were defeated by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Trick%20Shot%20%28comics%29">Trick Shot</a>.
Johnny Guitar and Doctor Sax, who were minor supervillains known for battling <a href="Dazzler%20%28comics%29">Dazzler</a>, later applied for membership into the Death-Throws. However, the two music-themed supervillains were quickly rejected on the basis that they couldn't juggle.
Going solo.
Bombshell underwent a genetic experiment to gain superpowers. She gained the ability to fire explosive energy blasts from her hands. Bombshell then joined an all female team of supervillains called the <a href="Femizons">Femizons</a>. The team were later defeated by Captain America. Bombshell's experimental new powers soon faded. <a href="Justin%20Hammer">Justin Hammer</a> hired a number of supervillains (including Bombshell) to battle <a href="Spider-Man">Spider-Man</a> and the <a href="New%20Warriors">New Warriors</a>. Justin Hammer and the supervillains then allied themselves with the <a href="Sphinx%20%28Marvel%20Comics%29">Sphinx</a> When Sphinx revealed his true intentions of total world domination, Bombshell panicked and fled.
After being seen playing a game of pool with <a href="8-Ball%20%28comics%29">8-Ball</a> in the Bar with No Name, Oddball was recruited by <a href="Doctor%20Octopus">Doctor Octopus</a> to join his incarnation of the <a href="Masters%20of%20Evil">Masters of Evil</a>. The team were quickly defeated by the <a href="Guardians%20of%20the%20Galaxy%20%281969%20team%29">Guardians of the Galaxy</a>. Oddball was later hired by Albino and <a href="Taskmaster%20%28comics%29">Taskmaster</a> to once again battle Hawkeye. He was defeated by the archer and the young <a href="Avengers%20%28comics%29">Avengers</a> recruits <a href="Vance%20Astrovik">Justice</a> and <a href="Firestar%20%28Marvel%20Comics%29">Firestar</a>. Oddball was later killed while taking part in the Bloodsport competition in <a href="Madripoor">Madripoor</a>. He was slain in the first round of the tournament by a tribal warrior called the Headhunter.
<a href="S.H.I.E.L.D.">S.H.I.E.L.D.</a> reported that Knickknack was killed and resurrected to serve <a href="Hydra%20%28Marvel%20Comics%29">HYDRA</a> and the <a href="Hand%20%28comics%29">Hand</a> as part of their supervillain army. All the supervillains involved were released from the Hand's control and returned to normal.
Return as team.
Orville Bock was hired by the Death-Throws to become the new Oddball, adopting the original Oddball's costume and trick juggling balls. The Death-Throws, along with <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a>, were hired by <a href="Advanced%20Idea%20Mechanics%23Splinter%20groups">R.A.I.D</a> to take part in a terrorist attack on <a href="London">London</a>. The team attacked civilians from the top of <a href="Tower%20Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, but soon come into conflict with <a href="Union%20Jack%20%28Joseph%20Chapman%29">Union Jack</a> and <a href="Sabra%20%28comics%29">Sabra</a>. Despite gaining the upper hand early in the battle, the Death-Throws and Crossfire were soon defeated. Bombshell, the last member of the team left standing, defused her bombs and surrendered.
The Death-Throws were among the supervillains researched by <a href="Quasimodo%20%28comics%29">Quasimodo</a>, on behalf of <a href="Green%20Goblin">Norman Osborn</a>, as potential villainous recruits for <a href="H.A.M.M.E.R.">H.A.M.M.E.R.</a> and the <a href="Fifty%20State%20Initiative">Initiative</a>. Knickknack later appeared as a member of <a href="Hood%20%28comics%29">Hood</a>'s crime syndicate. Bombshell, along with her previous employer Crossfire, was hired to join <a href="Misty%20Knight">Misty Knight</a>'s Villains for Hire team in a battle against the <a href="Purple%20Man">Purple Man</a>.
Members.
Bombshell.
Bombshell juggles various anti-personnel weapons including hand grenades, stun grenades, and smoke bombs.
Knickknack.
Nicholas "Nick" Grossman was born in <a href="Secaucus%2C%20New%20Jersey">Secaucus, New Jersey</a>. He later became a circus performer and juggler. Grossman then went to become a juggling supervillain known as the Knickknack and a member of the supervillain team, the Death-Throws. Knickknack was hired along with the Death-Throws by <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a> to help him escape from prison. The Death-Throws complete their mission, but decide to hold Crossfire hostage instead. The group are defeated and arrested by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Captain%20America">Captain America</a>. Later, Knickknack and the rest of the Death-Throws, along with various other supervillains, attempt to claim the bounty put on Hawkeye's right arm by Crossfire. However, all of the supervillains looking to claim the bounty are defeated by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Trick%20Shot%20%28comics%29">Trick Shot</a>. Later, Knickknack and the Death-Throws are hired by <a href="Advanced%20Idea%20Mechanics%23Splinter%20groups">R.A.I.D</a> to take part in a terrorist attack on <a href="London">London</a>. They attack civilians from the top of <a href="Tower%20Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, but soon come into battle with <a href="Union%20Jack%20%28Joseph%20Chapman%29">Union Jack</a> and <a href="Sabra%20%28comics%29">Sabra</a>. Knickknack appears as a member of <a href="Hood%20%28comics%29">Hood</a>'s crime syndicate. In flashback, Knickknack appears alongside Ringleader as he turns down Johnny Guitar and Doctor Sax for membership into the Death-Throws on the basis that the two music-themed supervillains couldn't juggle.
Powers and Abilities: Knickknack juggles an assortment of bladed instruments including meat cleavers, hunting knives and chainsaws.
Elton Healey.
Oddball juggles various trick juggling balls including acid balls, smoke balls, and explosive balls.
Orville Bock.
Like the original Oddball, this version of Oddball can also juggle various trick juggling balls including acid balls, smoke balls, and explosive balls.
Ringleader.
Charles Last was born in <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco, California</a>. He went to become a juggling supervillain known as the Ringleader and the leader of the supervillain team, the Death-Throws. Ringleader was hired along with the Death-Throws by <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a> to help him escape from prison. The Death-Throws complete their mission, but decide to hold Crossfire hostage instead. The group are defeated and arrested by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Captain%20America">Captain America</a>. Later, Ringleader and the rest of the Death-Throws, along with various other supervillains, attempt to claim the bounty put on Hawkeye's right arm by Crossfire. However, all of the supervillains looking to claim the bounty are defeated by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Trick%20Shot%20%28comics%29">Trick Shot</a>. Later, Ringleader and the Death-Throws are hired by <a href="Advanced%20Idea%20Mechanics">R.A.I.D</a> to take part in a terrorist attack on <a href="London">London</a>. They attack civilians from the top of <a href="Tower%20Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, but soon come into battle with <a href="Union%20Jack%20%28Joseph%20Chapman%29">Union Jack</a> and <a href="Sabra%20%28comics%29">Sabra</a>.In flashback, Ringleader turns down Johnny Guitar and Doctor Sax for membership into the Death-Throws on the basis that the two music-themed supervillains couldn't juggle.
Powers and Abilities: Ringleader juggles razor-sharp rings.
Tenpin.
Alvin Healey was born in <a href="Reno%2C%20Nevada">Reno, Nevada</a>. He went to become a juggling supervillain known as the Tenpin and a member of the Death-Throws supervillain team. When his brother Elton Healey (known as the supervillain <a href="Oddball%20%28comics%29">Oddball</a>) was arrested after an encounter with <a href="Hawkeye%20%28Clint%20Barton%29">Hawkeye</a>, Tenpin broke his brother out of prison.
Tenpin was hired along with the Death-Throws by <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a> to help escape from prison. The Death-Throws complete their mission, but decide to hold Crossfire hostage instead. The group are defeated and arrested by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Captain%20America">Captain America</a>. Later, Tenpin and the rest of the Death-Throws, along with various other supervillains, attempt to claim the bounty put on Hawkeye's right arm by Crossfire. However, all of the supervillains looking to claim the bounty are defeated by Hawkeye, Mockingbird and <a href="Trick%20Shot%20%28comics%29">Trick Shot</a>.
Tenpin's brother, Oddball, was killed while taking part in a Bloodsport tournament in Madripoor.
Later, Tenpin and the Death-Throws are hired by <a href="Advanced%20Idea%20Mechanics%23Splinter%20groups">R.A.I.D</a> to take part in a terrorist attack on <a href="London">London</a>. They attack civilians from the top of <a href="Tower%20Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, but soon come into battle with <a href="Union%20Jack%20%28Joseph%20Chapman%29">Union Jack</a> and <a href="Sabra%20%28comics%29">Sabra</a>.
Powers and Abilities: Tenpin is an expert juggler. He juggles with flaming, specially weighted, bowling pins which he also uses as projectiles. Tenpin also learned to be a street fighter in his younger days with his brother, Elton.
Death T.H.R.O.W.S..
In the past, the supervillain <a href="Crossfire%20%28comics%29">Crossfire</a> was known to employ the Death-Throws as his foot soldiers. However, deciding to leave behind the "fifth rate hacks in ridiculous costumes", Crossfire created a new army for himself. His "Death T.H.R.O.W.S". (Techno Hybrid Remotely Operated Weapons Systems) are robotic constructs that obey only his commands and each carry a small capable arsenal concealed within their armored shells. Crossfire used his Death T.H.R.O.W.S. to battle his old enemies <a href="Hawkeye%20%28Clint%20Barton%29">Hawkeye</a> and <a href="Mockingbird%20%28Marvel%20Comics%29">Mockingbird</a>.
Originally, the robotic Death T.H.R.O.W.S. were known as 'Magnum Z's'. The Magnum Z's were fully automated smart soldiers created for the United States. But the US senate ceased their development when they realised that the Magnum Z's abilities were in conflict with the <a href="Geneva%20Convention">Geneva Convention</a>. Crossfire acquired some of the defunct Magnum Z's to use in a plot to conquer the Isle of El Guapo, then later adapted them for his own purposes.
Other versions.
Mini Marvels.
The Death-Throws make a cameo appearance in the <a href="Mini%20Marvels">Mini Marvels</a> cartoon comic strip storyline "Paperboy Showdown" featured in "Spidey and the Mini Marvels" #1 (2003) and collected in "Mini Marvels: Ultimate Collection" (2009). The team can be seen playing basketball in the background in the <a href="Daily%20Bugle">Daily Bugle</a>'s paperboy training facility.
Solo versions.
Versions of Bombshell and Oddball have appeared in the "Last Avengers Story" #1-2 (1995) which is set in an alternative future. In the <a href="Ultimate%20Marvel">Ultimate Marvel</a> universe, two characters appear using the Bombshell codename. The Bombshells are a mother/daughter team of criminals. Lori Baumgartner and her young daughter Lana are mutants whose powers are activated when they are close to one another. They have the ability to fire explosive energy beams from their hands. In their first appearance, the foul-mouthed Bombshells attempted to rob a bank vault but are foiled by Spider-Man. Later, they attempted to rob an armored truck until the Human Torch and Spider-Woman arrived on the scene and defeated them.
